title: Sepsis Management Protocol
content: Initiate early goal-directed therapy for severe sepsis and septic shock. Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour of recognition. Fluid resuscitation with crystalloids. Identify and control the source of infection. Monitor lactate levels.

title: Pneumonia Standard Care Guidelines
content: Assess severity using CURB-65 or PSI. Obtain cultures before antibiotics if possible. Empiric antibiotic therapy based on likely pathogens and local resistance patterns. Oxygen therapy to maintain SpO2 > 92%. Consider corticosteroids for severe community-acquired pneumonia.

title: Diverticulitis Treatment Overview
content: For uncomplicated diverticulitis, outpatient management with clear liquids and oral antibiotics (e.g., ciprofloxacin and metronidazole) is often sufficient. Hospitalization for complicated cases (abscess, perforation, obstruction). Pain management is crucial. Follow-up colonoscopy recommended after resolution.

title: Hypertensive Emergency Management
content: Gradual reduction of mean arterial pressure (MAP) by no more than 10-20% within the first hour, then a further 5-15% over the next 23 hours. IV antihypertensives (e.g., labetalol, nicardipine, sodium nitroprusside) are preferred. Avoid rapid drops in BP which can lead to ischemia.

title: Acute Myocardial Infarction (MI) Initial Care
content: Administer aspirin and antiplatelet therapy (e.g., clopidogrel or ticagrelor). Oxygen if SpO2 < 90%. Nitroglycerin for chest pain, unless contraindicated. Morphine for persistent pain. Beta-blockers within 24 hours if no contraindications. Early reperfusion therapy (PCI or fibrinolysis) is key.
